title: Bake Off Nadiya Hussain was criticised for being a housewife
text:
Nadiya was criticised for giving up work (Picture: Shirlaine Forrest/WireImage)

Nadiya Hussain has admitted that being criticised for being a housewife after winning the Great British Bake Off ‘cut like a knife’.

The 34-year-old became a bit of a national treasure when she won the sixth series of The Great British Bake Off back in 2015, and has gone on to present The Chronicles of Nadiya, Nadiya’s British Food Adventure and Nadiya’s Family Favourites.

However, after winning Bake Off, the mother-of-three felt that she had to justify staying at home to take care of her kids.

Speaking on the podcast Out For Lunch with Jay Rayner, Nadiya said: ‘The moment my name was announced as winner of Bake Off, one of the very first articles was about how I was on the only one who didn’t have a job. It said housewife underneath and it said she must be on benefits. That really knocked me for six.

Nadiya appeared on Jay Rayner’s podcast

‘Part of me was expecting those sorts of comments to come up and I was a housewife and I maintain to this day that it was the best job I have ever done. It the most rewarding, least paid but the most rewarding.

‘At the time that cut like a knife because for somebody who had worked really hard up until the point I got married, I stopped working just to raise my children because I couldn’t afford to pay childcare so I had to stay at home with my kids. And I never felt the need to justify my decisions but suddenly you are put in a position where you have justify your decisions and choices and that was really hard to deal with because here I am Muslim woman, it’s like how does it feel? I don’t know, what am I doing, I haven’t done anything.

‘I was just a really anxious person dealing really badly with panic disorder who just wanted to do something for herself.’

The chef added that she didn’t tell her parents that she was on the show until week eight.

Nadiya told food critic Jay: ‘I was finally doing something for me, and I’ve been told all my life, you’re a girl, you can’t do this, you shouldn’t be doing that. I didn’t tell anyone. I know the instant reaction would be.

‘What, you’re leaving your children and your husband to go and fanny about on this cookery show. What’s going on? I knew that’s what I would get straight away so I decided that I wasn’t going to tell anyone. I didn’t tell my parents until about week eight. Bearing in mind that my parents don’t watch Bake Off, they didn’t understand what it was I was doing.’

It’s not only Nadiya who has received criticism since her time on Bake Off, as her husband Abdal has also received abuse due to Nadiya’s status.

She explained: ‘In all cultures men are seen as the breadwinners, they are the one that bring the bacon home I suppose, and the world doesn’t work like that.

‘It just isn’t like that anymore. Women work, men work and it’s a partnership and it’s a combination.’

Out To Lunch with Jay Rayner season two is out now.
